awd_titl_txt: Molecular-level Understanding Of Atmospheric Aerosols (MUOAA 2024); Corsica, France; April 1-5, 2024
awd_abstract_narration:
This project provides support for US scientists to attend the Conference on Molecular-Level Understanding of Atmospheric Aerosols to be held in Corsica, France, on April 1-5, 2024. The objective of the conference is to provide molecular level perspectives on aerosol properties that are critical to the impact of aerosols on air quality, climate, and environmental as well as human health.

Challenges currently exist in understanding the formation of aerosol particles from gaseous precursors and the initial growth of these particles, the internal structure of aerosols, aerosol phase behavior, heterogeneous and multiphase (photo)chemistry, gas-surface interactions, the ability of aerosols to initiate ice and cloud nucleation, the evolution of aerosol optical properties, and the role of bioaerosols in the atmosphere. The conference will take place over five days and include oral and poster sessions spanning the topics listed above.

The majority of the support for the conference will go toward travel support for student, postdoctoral, and early career professionals to help promote their careers. The meeting agenda, presentation titles, and abstracts will be archived on the meeting website, open and available to all. Summaries of the discussions will also be archived on the website.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Environmental quality and climate change are pressing global challenges, and understanding atmospheric processes is essential to predict and manage climate impacts at both short and long-term scales. Atmospheric aerosols play a critical role in these processes. Recent research has highlighted significant barriers in our molecular understanding of aerosols, which must be addressed through fundamental laboratory, theoretical, and modeling studies in chemistry and physics. Key areas of focus include aerosol formation from gaseous precursors, particle growth, aerosol phase behavior, cloud nucleation, and the interaction of aerosols with light and biological systems.

The Molecular Understanding of Atmospheric Aerosols (MUOAA) event successfully brought together 88 participants from around the world to tackle these issues. The symposium’s interdisciplinary nature facilitated connections across fields such as atmospheric science, chemistry, chemical engineering, and physics, fostering collaboration among experts who don’t typically interact at specialized conferences. Importantly, around 40% of attendees were early-career scientists, enabling them to engage in meaningful discussions with leading researchers, gaining insights into both current research and career development opportunities.

The event featured an intensive program with a single session track that included 15-35 minute talks followed by lively discussions. A key feature was the daily feedback session from PhD students, which sparked cross-generational dialogue, further enriching the experience. Discussions continued throughout the day, both during breaks and in informal settings, fostering networking and idea-sharing.

Key research topics discussed included the properties and impacts of aerosols, particularly those from combustion sources like biomass burning organic aerosols, with a focus on their molecular characterization using advanced mass spectrometry techniques. Attendees also explored aerosol interactions with water and their chemical dynamics in both outdoor and indoor environments, focusing on complex surface and interface chemistry. The role of liquid atmospheric particles in photochemical transformations was also highlighted, as was the toxicological and organic chemical characterization of aerosols.

In conclusion, MUOAA facilitated important interdisciplinary exchanges and led to concrete follow-up actions in the field of aerosol science. The event, supported by NSF, not only advanced our scientific understanding but also helped build a network of researchers dedicated to addressing the complex challenges of aerosol behavior in atmospheric processes. Specifically, NSF support was critical for helping US attendees overcome the travel barrier costs to this conference.
